comments.body:
Can you clarify this regex with some examples in the comment? 
According to https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2818#section-3.1,  `f*.com matches foo.com but not bar.com`, but this regex will fail `f*.com` right? Also https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6125#section-6.4.3 states that only the leftmost label will tolerate a `*`, which I believe this regex handles. Users on slack noticed that the go library was recently modified to accomodate this (https://github.com/golang/go/commit/e7fae6854008c163ba83e2eac52ae9f12003a9a9).

done. 

I also added tests for `IsWildcardDNS1123Subdomain`
did i miss your change? this will still reject "f*.com" right? https://play.golang.org/p/rVxw0LEFx1

yes
`validation_test.go:428: expected errors for "f*.com": [must match the regex \*\.[a-z0-9]([-a-z0-9]*[a-z0-9])?(\.[a-z0-9]([-a-z0-9]*[a-z0-9])?)* (e.g. '*.example.com')]`
was looking at the wrong rfc, yeah f*.com is invalid.

comments.body: These were public because they are being used by downstream code not in this package to present consistent messages. and values.  I'm not sure hiding them still allows that - @deads2k

> These were public because they are being used by downstream code not in this package to present consistent messages. and values. I'm not sure hiding them still allows that - @deads2k

with the string slice returned below, I think we'll be ok.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +28,32 @@const qnameCharFmt string = "[A-Za-z0-9]"
const qnameExtCharFmt string = "[-A-Za-z0-9_.]"
const qualifiedNameFmt string = "(" + qnameCharFmt + qnameExtCharFmt + "*)?" + qnameCharFmt
const qualifiedNameMaxLength int = 63

comments.body: if nobody else calls IsValidIPv4() why not just get rid of that function?

We have some incompat going on.  UNIXes generally leave room for -1 and -2 UIDs to mean something, but they usually define uid_t as unsigned. If we're treating UID as signed just because Docker does - is that kosher?  It's probably not a huge issue, but it seems a bit off.
